title.narrative: THIRD NATIONAL FADAMA DEVELOPMENT PROJECT (FADAMA III)

description.narrative: The development objective of the Third National Fadama Development Project for Nigeria is to increase the incomes for users of rural lands and water resources in a sustainable manner and to contribute to restoration of the livelihoods of conflict affected households in the selected area in the North East (NE) of the Recipient's territory. The additional financing proposes to finance two components. A new component will be introduced to the ongoing project, (Component 7: Food Security and Livelihoods Support Investment Program) and an existing component (Project management and evaluation (M&E) will be scaled-up to support project implementation. The project closing date would be extended by two years from December 31, 2017 to December 31, 2019; the Result Framework for the parent project will be revised to reflect the change in scope and the new closing date of December 31, 2019 and to also include indicators to track the outcome and results of activities to be implemented in the NE financed under the new additional financing (AFII); cost allocation by component and category will be updated to accommodate the new additional Component 7; and two new safeguard policies will be triggered including Physical Cultural Resources (OP/BP 4.11) and Safety of Dams (OP/BP 4.37).

participating-org.narrative: Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Financing Agreement | Description :the Recipient shall maintain at all times during the Projectimplementationperiod, the following agencies: (i) NFTC; (ii) Department of Extension Services; and (iii) NFCO, including a desk officeresponsible for project activities in the North East, all in form and with mandates, resources, and qualified and experienced staffin adequate numbers, satisfactory to the Assoc | Due Date :30-Jun-2016

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2. Sec I. Para 4 (b) | Description :The Recipient shall cause each Participating State to maintain atall times during the implementation of the Project, its PFMU | Due Date :30-Jun-2010

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2. Sec I. Para 5 (a) | Description :The Recipient shall prepare and furnish to IDA for its approval,not later than September 30 each year annual work plans and budgets containing proposed subprojects for the following calendar year| Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2. Sec II. Para A. 1. | Description :The Recipient shall monitor and evaluate the progress of theProject and prepare Project Reports furnished to IDA not later than 30days after the end of the period covered by such report. |Frequency :Quarterly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2. Sec II. Para B. 2. | Description :The Recipient shall prepare and furnish to the Association, notlater than 30 days after the end of each calendar quarter, interim unaudited financial reports for the Project covering the quarter| Frequency :Quarterly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2. Sec II. Para B. 3. | Description :The audited Financial Statements covering the period of one fiscalyear shall be furnished to the Association not later than six months after the end of such period | Frequency :Yearly

title.narrative: 40% increase in yield cassava, rice, sorghum, and horticulture and 20% increase in yield of primary agricultural products (disaggregated by crops/agroforestry, livestock and fisheries, etc.) of partic
75% of beneficiaries, who benefit directly from Project supported activities, have increased their average real incomes by at least40%.
Number of Fadama User Groups (FUGs) and Fadama Community Association (FCAs) registered
Number of productive rural infrastructure constructed in the participating communities (disaggregated by feeder roads, culverts / small bridges)
10% of replacement value of the common asset used by the beneficiaries for income generating activities is saved annually (with effect from year 2).
Number of FUGs and FCAs receiving grant resources for procuring rural advisory services under the project
Number of FUGs and FCAs receiving matching grant for the purchase of agricultural inputs under the project
Number of Local Government Authority (LGA) staff trained in Project Mgt Skills (Project planning, Cost Benefit Analysis, Financial Mgt., M&E & Social Mobilization
Number of equipments acquired by FUGs and FCAs in the participating states (disaggregated by Crop production, livestock, fisheries,forestry, agro-processing)
20% increase in income from sales of value added agricultural products
Number of ADP staff trained in the management and delivery of extension services
100% of participating Fadama Communities have at least one productive rural infrastrucutre constructed / rehabilitated (disaggregated by feeder raods, culverts/small bridges)
By end of project, 20% of participating Local Government Authorities integrate Local Development Plans into their annual plans.
Number of research institutes that received research grant under the project
30% of FCAs have access to market information
Number of FUGs and FCAs trained
By end of project, 75% of FUGs and FCAs have fully (100%) implemented approved LDPs
Number of information dissemination media available in participating states (disaggregated by media types)
75 percent of beneficiaries are satisfied with operations, maintenance, and utilization of community-owned infrastructure and capital assets acquired through the Project.
50% increase in the number of Fadama farmers with access to agricultural inputs (disaggregated by gender and vulnerable groups)
By Mid Term Review, 75% of participating communities have Local Development Plans (LDPs) developed through a participatory process
20% increase in new technology adopted in Fadama communities (disaggregated by technology, gender, vulnerable groups, age and farm size).
50% of assets and community-owned infrastructure are operating satisfactorily and are maintained and utilized.
30% increase in the number if Fadama farmers receiving extension services from ADPs (Disaggregated by gender and vulverable groups)
Direct Project beneficiaries (%of which is female)
30% increase in the number of Fadama users procuring rural advisory services in the participating communities (disaggregated by gender and vulnerable groups).
Submission of periodic report of satisfactory project management
Percentage of beneficiaries receiving Nutrition Awareness information
Pecentage of beneficiaries using inputs rich in micro – nutrients
Percentage of beneficiaries that have successfully negotiated contracts
Community/farmer organizations trained for technical and managerial skills
Villages/settlements engaged in participatory processes for site and beneficiary selection
Days of work provided to returnees and conflict affected households
Male Project Beneficiaries in the North East
Direct Project beneficiaries household in the North East (%of which is female)
Female Direct Project Beneficiaries Household in the North East
